This poor afflicted Province was my Dowry:
And the o'er-hasty judging world will say,
According to the Censure pass'd on me,
My Trespass drew this Evil on the Land.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tis better that the world should judge so, and perish
For it in it's Ignorance, then you so wilfully
Be cast away: you hear that none escape.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: None, Old nor Young, Man, Woman Child, all
In one kinde or other, do feel Affliction.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Do any die?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: None, though the most do wish
They might, in lieu of their sad sufferings.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: And whither now do you intend your travail with your griefs?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: We hope a better Air will cure us. But
We are advis'd by our Divines and Augurs,
By the best means we can, to make our Journey
Towards the Court, to send our sad complaint
Unto the King.

sp.speaker: (Eul.
sp.l: Hear now what he will say)

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: They find by Divination, that this punishment
Is falne upon this Province by the Sin
Of the Adulterous Queen, whose Dowrie 'twas.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: And that until
His justice take away Her loathed life,
This evil will not cease.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, the Queen Eulalia's life?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes Sir; we hear shee's banish'd, and forbid relief:
But nothing save her polluted blood must quench this flame,
In expiation of her Sin and shame.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dare you stay longer here? pray let us flie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Why then you think me guiltie, Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not what to think, but that I will not.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Was that your Priests opinion and advice?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes, and thus grounded, that our pains began
Just at the hour, the Kings Indulgencie
Releas'd her forfeit Life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: 'Twas everso; Priests are but Apes to Kings,
And prostitute Religion to their ends.
sp.p: Might you not judge as well, it was th' injustice and the wrongs the innocent Queen hath suffer'd, that has brought sense of her injuries upon her Province? And that if she had died, her Dowrie here with her had also suffered Death? to make it nothing to the King, as he made her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I, mark ye that: and that your false surmise
Against the Queen has brought this evil on you.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: O now my pain increases. 1. O mine Eyes. 2. My Brain. 3. My Bones. 4. My limbs are on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, your fowl mistrust is the infection that rages in you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Lodovico, peace: where is thy pain good man?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: Here in this Arm shrunk up as it were sear'd with fiery Irons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Bless'd Providence assist me whilst with Prayers I use the gift thou gav'st me for the cure of these afflicted People. Give me thine hand: what feelst thou now?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: A precious cooling Balm that has extinguished
The scorching heat I felt, and has reduc'd
My Flesh, my Sinews, and my Arteries,
Into their natural temper and true use.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Joyn that hand to thy other, and thank Heaven then
sp.l: That made thee whole.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Miraculous!

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O sure you are some Heavenly Saint or Goddess.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Beware Idolatry, and onely send
All praise to th' power whose mercy hath no end.
Onely do this for me: inform the rest
How you have sped, and win them back again,
To the next village: bid them be of chear,
Whilst I make Holy Prayers for their help.
Ile come and live among you for my hire,
Which shall be cheap, believe me.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: All we have
Will be too slight reward: first take my store.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I will but take my next competent meal.
I hope this will be thought but valuable.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I pray take more.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go back I say with your sad company,
And comfort them with news of your success,
And a full hope of cure to every one
That's Partner in this sad Affliction.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: With happy feet I shall spread it through the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O happy woman, now no more a Queen,
But Holy Saint: I see how Providence
Means to advance thy injur'd innocence.
Ile dwell here now my self, and without fear:
For perfect health I think dwells only where
Good Eulalia remains: I have enough
To buy a Farm for me and poor Andrea.
But what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Ile tell you, Lodovico: the poor Fellow
Is gone to taste the Countrey Air for me,
Lest I might be infected: you shall see
Straight how he speeds.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And that was honest love.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A Surgeon, a Surgeon! Oh a Surgeon!

sp.speaker: Eul,
sp.l: How now, Andrea?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: A Surgeon: Oh twentie Surgeons, bonesetting Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: What's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I am out of joynt. Ile taste no more of such contagious Aires, To save as many Queens as I have hairs. Oh Surgeons and Bone-setters, Bone-setters and Surgeons, all my Bones, all my Bones for a penny.
sp.l: I have not a finger nor a toe in joynt: my Leggs,
my Thighs, my Arms, my neck.
My back and Crupperbone is out of joynt.
Oh for a Sowgelder, a Surgeon I would say.
Out a joynt, out a joynt, I am all out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Thy tongue's not out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, nor a Thing
I have that has no Bone in't: All else is out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This came of tempting Providence: were not you
Told the danger by the many that smarted of it?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I met them all dancing and frisking home.
The blind man made the way: the dumb man sung,
The deaf kept time to his Notes: the lame led on
The Dance to all the rest: whilst I can go
No further. [lies down ]'Twas for you I ventured.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: And now you repent you meant me so much good.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And now again I do repent that ever I did repent. Oh for a Stone-cutter, a Bone-setter I would say.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Well Sir, give me your hands: stand up.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: With as good a will as ever I stood to woman.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Now, how do you feel your self?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: In very pretty plight, I feel I am sufficient.
sp.p: Haugh, heigh— [Capers and turns ]'twill do again: and if I durst venture into that unluckie Countrey again, I would now teach the Clowns how to Dance for joy.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes you shall venter Sir; and by the way,
Ile teach you to teach them to work and pray.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: To work and play I pray you,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If there be Heaven on earth, it is this woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Then if there be a Purgatorie on earth,
Ile venter through it for her, heigh, o, ho.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.l: 1. Health and Joy: Health and Joy.
2. O happy woman that ever she came hither!
1. Nay happy we that ere she came among us.
2. What shall we render her in recompence?
All that we have is too little for this woman,
This good woman, this holy woman, this she-Saint,
If there be one above ground.
3. O do not make an If at her, neighbour, lest the ground swallow thee quick in thy Infidelitie.
2. Now doubtless, and without all adventure, she is an unknown woman.
3. And therefore a good woman: for 'tis too true,
All those that are well known are e'en bad enough:
And known she will not be for all our entreats,
No not so much as from whence she came, we see.
2. And that counsel she may keep still for me:
For doubtless, and without all peradventure
If we had need of another such, 'it were in vain to seek her.
1. Sure 'twas from Heaven she came,
Where the whole stock of good women were plac'd long ago.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis she I'm confident.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Our work lies fairly then before us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: These look like mischievous Robbers.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What can they take from us?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your Life, I fear.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I have e'en din'd, let 'em take away when they please.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Their looks are murderous.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Fear not, Lodovico: why look ye Friends, so amazedly? ha'ye lost your way? or what do ye seek?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No, we ha' found our way, 'tis to you we seek: we dare come roundly to you, for all your
sp.l: Guard, your old Fool, and your young here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O my unhappy Fears!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You will not murder me?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis all the Office we are bound to doe you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Just Heaven protect me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Call upon Heaven as you go thitherward:
We may not stay long Invocations.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray take me in your way, and run me through her, if you be honest Murderers. Help: Murder, Murder!

div.head: Scoen. VII.
div.stage: Enter to them, Curate, Crier, Pedro, Lollio, Poggio.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes! O yes! O yes!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Silence Crier, suspend the Proclamation, to prevent abomination.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Heaven has sent us ayd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O we are prevented!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
On, on; sa, sa; down with their Weapons, up with their heels, till we insect and rip up the intrails of the Cause: what an Assassinate was here attempted?
O infausta Dies! two swords against the naked womb of a Woman! and none but weaponless men to assist her!

sp.speaker: viz.
sp.l: Senex & Ineptus.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: That is to say, Give me their Swords under my Fools Coat, I'll hurt no body.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Upon my facundity, an elegant construction by the Fool. So, I am cedunt arma Togae.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: For our attempt Sir, we will answer it: we are for the King.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then we are for the King, Sir; & in nomine
Majestatis, we command you to attend our present
Office, and then we will examine yours.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: And then if you deserve the Gallows, you shall be sure on't: a short breathing-while shall be no hinderance to you. So Crier lift up your Voice, and proceed.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes, O yes, O yes: By the Kings most Excellent Majesty, a Proclamation, prohibiting upon pain of Death, any Relief to be given unto the banish'd Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now say, Whereas upon just and lawful Tryal.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: Whereas, &c.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The said Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: The said Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: I am that hapless she, that for relief will not beg, nor borrow, nor take of yee.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis she, and at the price of Life I will relieve her.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How? what have we done? In relieving her from killing, we are all become Traytors.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: That's an idle fear: we knew her not,
Which now we do, we may again reliver her
Into their hands, for them to kill her yet:
And then there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: So let us give them their swords again; and
when they have done their work, to make all sure,
we'll hang them for their pains, and so keep the Law
in our own hands while we have it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O homines insani! quomodo erravistis?
The woman must be sav'd á manubus istis.
They are Catilinarian Traytors.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You Sir, have reason; you have found her Life
The King has pardon'd: and although her Doom
In this her Banishment were heavy, and
A punishment even unto Death, but that
Good soul she works and labours for her food,
You find not yet 'tis lawful any kill her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Recte dixisti Domine: therefore Sir,
You that are for the King, as you pretend,
Shew us th' Imperative mood or warrant for her death,
Or we shall put you into the Optativa mood,
By punishment to wish your selves dead oftner
Or more times than bona fide there be Tenses
In all the Moods of all my Accidences.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: For my part Ile forgive them, if they will
Deliver truely who corrupted them,
To rid the world of this weary burden; that I may pray for them.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Can such a goodness deserve so fowl a Censure?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: But first tell me: Are not you two the men that gave false evidence at my Arraignment touching injur'd Sforza?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We gave no evidence, nor false nor true.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: No countrey-woman, they had no such Beards. But I will try if I can make'm like'em: O rare! what a nimble Barber am I? Lod. They are the self-same men, the two cashier'd Lieutenants that Sforza should have hang'd for mutinies in the late Wars.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: What hinders now their execution?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Digito compesce labellum: silence good Pedro.
I do commend your zeal: but Periculum est in via,
We will walk safely: for this time therefore wee'l do onely thus,
Double our guards upon 'em, and away to prison with them,
Est locus in carcere quod Tullianum appellatur.
We will presume to know who 'twas that set you awork, before you go,

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: You will be made to answer it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A word more, wee'l hang you presently, and answer that too: Abite hinc in malam Rem: away with 'm.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: Ah Rogues, wee'l hamper ye.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: Kill a woman 'cause she was a Queen?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Wee'l hamper ye, and halter ye, and do ye hear? hang ye.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lollio and Poggio, with Fabio and Strozza.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Abi hinc & malam rem, away with'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: As I am Erudite, idoneus Adolescens,
A very towardly Juvenis. Cupis atque doceri?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: After you is manners.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now by mine intellect, discreetly spoken.
Be but my Pupil, I will make thee one,
And dip thy Caput in pure Helicon.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Pray what's my Caput? and what's your Helicon?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Still a desire to learn: this is no Fool.
And by the company hee's in, I do suspect,
Simile non est Idem: hee's too wise,
To be the thing he seems but in disguise:
Some Lord of Court, his outside non obstante.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It is confess'd Sir, I am Lodovico,
Somtimes a Lord of Court when this was Queen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O Oedipus! I meant this Juvenal.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No truely Sir, your Simile non est Idem.
I am no Lord, what ere you like me to.
What I may pass for in the Country I know not,
At Court I was a Fool when she was Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We dare not call her Queen now: but while we
Relieve her not, though we associate her,
We are the Kings true Subjects: and with your leave,
Disclaiming of all Honourable Titles,
We'll live amongst ye.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O gracious woman, so I may safely call you,
Who once preserv'd my life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Mention not that.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I ought not to conceal it: therefore know
That some years past being imploy'd to Court
To render the Kings Rents for this Province:
Which though I duely did, there was a Lord,
A strange officious one, that charg'd me deeply,
And all our Province, with detested breach
Of our Allegiance: at which my rage
Banish'd my reason, and confounded so
My senses, that without respect of Person,
Or Place, which was the Danger of the Law,
I struck him there in Court: and was adjudg'd
To suffer death for't, till you won my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Were you that man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And 'twas my
Cozen Lord' I warrant that you box'd.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis he that braggs so much his truth unto the Crown; I need not name him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sed nunc quid sequitur? Pray mark the issue of this Court quarrell. By the way, 'tis well you have renounc'd all qualitie of Court.
sp.l: Here were no living for you else; for know,
Since this mans trouble, not a Gentleman,
Much less a Courtier dares breath amongst us,
But be as you pretend and write, but Yeoman:
You shall live Jovially with us and welcome,
At your own charge, your own Viaticum.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: We have laid up
The murderous minded men in dungeon deep,
Clogg'd them with Ploughchains, Fetters and Horse-locks.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: We'l teach 'm to kill Queens:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Cave, caveto.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: We mean this woman, this discarded Queen.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For all the Feasts, the Triumphs and the Glories
That have been spent, at price of great Estates,
In celebration of my high Advancement;
For all the King has in his present being,
His Love to boot, assur'd in highest measure;
Me-thinks there is yet wanting an Addition
To crown my Happiness: all's not safe hereafter;
I cannot safely say I am his Wife,
While th'other seems contented with a Life. Flavello!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Most Mighty Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O most Coelestial sound!
Here's all your business granted.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Greatest and best of Queens! All?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: See the Kings hand to all: do you mistrust me?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I onely look for the poor womans Pardon
That kill'd her Husband for his gelding the Priest.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: If you but manage the Profits of my Favours with a discreet Hand now, you may soon finde the difference between a Mignion, and the Son of a Dish-Maker.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I finde it in your Gifts, my bounteous Goddess.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Oh Divine!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: And would presume that
I my self were worthy
A place i'th' Kalendar, might I do you Service,
That merited the smallest of your Graces.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Do you know the village where that woman lives?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Who, sacred Deitie?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I'm very sick to name her or her Son.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: O Eulalia; yes, the very House: 'tis in your Majesties way now, as you pass to Nicosia: the King is ready, Madam, and calls away; he longs to be at the end of his journey, to perform his Duty in the three Grants belong to you.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O but that Woman, and that hated Boy.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Eulalia, Madam?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Thou art a base
Ingrateful Villain to name her to me;
Thou hear'st me say, I dare not speak her name,
Yet thou dar'st stab mine Ears again, with it.
Had some receiv'd the Favours thou hast done,
Or could but dream of half thou'rt like to have,
I should not fear her Ghost; but thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O let me take new spirit from your hand,
And say unto your self, She is sure dead.
But the King comes. I am enough inspir'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will not onely have you guiltless, Sir,
But free from least suspect; let but a spark
Of Discontent appear upon your Look,
I'll rip the hollow cave that holds the fire,
And with Death quench it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I beseech your Highness,
If any alteration in my looks
Be found, or read, let it as well be construed,
It grows but from a filial fear t'offend.
I have forgot I had another Mother:
And humbly at the Feet of this I honour,
I beg her Ayd, to win your Favour towards me.
Most gracious Madam, if you knew the Truth,
The fair sincerity I bear in Duty
Towards your Highness—

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For what respect, young Prince?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: The principal i'th' World: For that you have
My Fathers Love; and but to Wrong or Grieve you,
Were Stripes or Wounds to his Affection.
So much of my late Mother I remember,
To yield a Reverence to his Contentment, and shall for ever.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: My Lord, my Love, what pretty meaning have you?
Do you bring your Son to mock me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! my Alinda, he's no Son of mine,
That with lesse Adoration dares look up
On thy Divinity, then the Aegyptians
Gave to the Sun it self: but an out-cast Bastard,
And of the daring Giants ignorant Nature,
That war'd against the Gods.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: I would not move your Anger: pray let this win your Reconcilement.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O thou art gentle, and the life of Sweetness:
Come, my Alinda, I was calling you
To our intended Journey to Nicosta,
Where solemnly I will perform my Vow,
To grant the three demands I promis'd you,
In the full view of our Nobility.
Which by the Custome of my Predecessors
Have ratified and confirm'd the Power
Of Queens, and made them absolute: have you thought
To ask things worthy of your Dignity,
Wherein I fully may declare my Bounty?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I, Sir, shall be so reasonable, that
I doubt not upon the way, or there at very instant,
To crave past my Desert.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O you are modest: but ask home, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: And by the way, Sir, let it be my Suit,
We give a Visit to distrest Eulalia;
Wherein we may do Charity fitting Princes;
(We may perhaps give Order for her Burial)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art all Goodness: Come, all Friends, Gonzago:
But thank her Clemency.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: An Earldome be thou sure of, wise Flavello,
To add to thy improvements: Though it be
No full Discovery, I'll make it serve,
As I will fashion it, to excellent use.
Poyson or Sword thou heardst him speak?

sp.speaker: Elav.
sp.l: And in a menacing way: Now what may be
Conjectur'd by such words, from men whose looks
Shew discontent against your Mightiness,
Rests most considerable.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Write, Flavello, write,
Write by that Copy in a States-Man's hand.
Alas, good men! I dare even swear for them,
How ere those words might fall in their discourse,
They had no thought of me: yet this surmise
Gives me an hint to try her Loyaltie,
Or make her once more guiltie: for my State
Stands by the King, as unto her his hate.
Read it Flavello.

quote.p: Most Royal and most wronged Soveraign Mistress, be happily assured that the time of your Restoration is at hand: and that by no loss means then the death of that she-monster that usurps your Dignitie. All shall be determin'd at Nicosia, by
Your devoted Servant unto death. Nameless.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: 'Tis well.
It needs no superscription: only seal it,
And think of your directions and disguise.
'Tis but your half days journey: and be sure
We are not far behind you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I flie, my Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now to the King,
Of whose despight I still must sharp the sting.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No news of Lodovico yet, Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: None since he stole from Court upon the Banishment
Of that false wicked woman, whom I cannot
Name to your face or forehead, but I tremble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Because you fear all horned Beasts.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Loyalty forbid,
And my infallible Truth unto the Crown,
But I were sensible of the injury.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know thy Loyalty: but as for Lodovico,
How was my Judgement wrong'd in him!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thought my self as safe in that mans Counsel—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And so did I,
By my lov'd Loyalty, think my self safe
In his Advices—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet methought he had
A kinde of slyness in his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, he had ever a kind of a slie look.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That still methought I had a Genius
That check'd my forward love, and did inform me
That he would prove disloyal: and for that cause,
To speak plain truth, I never lov'd him truely.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Will your Majesty believe me? I would I might never rise
Into your Favour (and that I would not say
For all the Traytors Lands in your Kingdom,
Which were no small reward) if that were not
Mine very own conceit of Lodovico
That Traytor; hang him: what should I call him less?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet 'twas given out you lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: So 'twas thought your Highness did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that he was your yoak-fellow in the State.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, when he's hang'd he shall be King. How Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your Majesty knows my thoughts: nay I thank my creation, I was ever
Just of your Majesties mind from my Nativitie,
And in that faith Ile die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here's a true Statesman now!
Go, send Gonzago to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My sweet yong Prince?
I shall: but ere I go,
Let me inform your Highness in my thoughts
Of the sweet Prince Gonzago: if ever King
Was happy in a Son, you are in him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go, call him to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Cherish him, good my Lord:
Hee'l be a sure staff to you in your Age,
And prove a Statesman quickly: I cannot think,
Except in him and your undoubted Queen,
Petruccio and my self, True Loyalty lives.
And here he comes: obedience in his Face
Most brightly shining.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wait without Horatio.
Gonzago?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My dread Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did you attempt
Against my strict command to visit Sforza?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: It is most true, I did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Gracious Heaven forbid it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What was your purpose?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: First on my knees let me implore your Royal Pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My end was noble: as I thought, well suiting
The Honour of a Prince: I would have search'd
Into the secrets of his heart by questions,
Whether he had intended or conceived
Treason against your Highness, as it is
Presum'd he did: for which he was committed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My self for that was his Accuser;
How durst you then make a scruple at it?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Still relying on your Pardon, I had thought
T'have won confession of it from himself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Suppose he had confess'd it?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: I had then
Concluded there had been a Probabilitie
Of my poor mothers falsehood: yet I would have put
That Question to him next.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And say
He had confess'd that too?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Then had I sav'd
Your Laws a needless labour in his death;
And with the same hand made that mother childless,
That by her folly forfeited her Husband.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was that your resolution? but suppose
He had denied all?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: All had then been nothing
But a Scandal to my mother and himself:
So good a Souldier would not be a lyer
To save an abject life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are
His Bastard, not my son, in doing this.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: You are my King, would I could say, my Father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Within there!
Horatio, would you think it? this young stripling
Takes part against me with that Traytor Sforza.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Does your Grace think so?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Think so? I know it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then I know it too: Think, did you say? I think 'twas time to think it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I knew it not till now.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As I am true to th' Crown, just now I knew it too.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O do not so interpret, Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What can be said against it? has not his Grace spoke it?
What must be done with him to please your Majesty?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Convey him from my sight, and let our Marshal
Petruccio take him to safe custody,
Till our further pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My King, and Father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence with him I say.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Great Sir, your mercy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Did not I tell your Majesty there was not,
But in the Queen, Petruccio, and my self,
True Loyaltie in the Court? Away you Traytorling.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My Lord, you are too severe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What? in being true to th' Crown? O my Loyaltie!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No news yet? no return?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: We shall have, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You made not choise of men of Resolution.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: They were the same exasperate cashier'd Souldiers
That sware so valiantly against Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Many that pass for Souldiers dare swear valiantly,
That dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Many that dare not fight,
Dare do a murther Madam, such a tame one too.
I am confident they have kill'd her: however, I have done my best.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou hast done nothing whilst that woman lives.
The work was not so course, that your own hand
Could have disdain'd it, Sir, if you had lov'd me.
So leave me, negligent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Her first months Majesty hath wip'd out
The memorie of all her former dayes.
I must not lose her though: this hand then soon
Must do the work, be 't not already done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How cheers my love? what ominous aspect
Hath wrought this sad Eclipse upon that Beautie,
Whose radiancie onely is my life?
Cast by this veil of sadness: quit my fears,
And from my Browes wipe off a score of years.
No? what must then remove it? or dispell
These Clouds, that from the anguish of thy heart
Do cast this shadow ore my happiness?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I must not, will not name it: but you said
You would do something, which it seems
Your wavering love neglects.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Can I neglect
A duty that belongs to my Alinda?
Speak it again: and by my first nights bliss
I had with thee, by this kiss, and by this,
Ile treble in performance all my promises.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Y'are dull in your performances: I will
Not name a request the second time, although my life,
Your dignitie, and your Kingdoms safetie,
Lie on the rack for 't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She will not name 't again:
Her last request was for the head of Sforza,
Her arrogant proud Father, whose perversness
Checq'd at her due promotion; and whose life
Swolne up with Popularitie, was my danger,
Threatning no less then ruine on my State.
She will not name 't again, poor tender soul,
Lest she might fall into th' interpretation
Of an unnatural child: yet for my safetie,
She suffers in desire to have it done.
I have prevented her desire, 'tis done:
I know Petruccio his Antagonist,
Who had my warrant and Signet for it,
Would not be slack in th' execution.
Come, sweet, be fearless: that which your mild goodness
Is now so timerous to name, is done.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is she pursu'd and put to death?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What she?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Nay, I have said again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sforza, my dearest life, th' unnatural Homicide
That sought thy life and mine, is put to death.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What, my dear Father?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was it not your Desire?
Here comes sure Testimony: speak Petruccio;
I will not ask, Is 't done? but speak the manner
How Sforza di'd.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A self-wil'd obstinate man:
Such as he liv'd he di'd: and gracious Madam,
That a more bloody Spectacle should not move
Your tender nature to compunction, I brought
But this inseparate Adjunct of his malicious Head
Against you, the King, and the whole Kingdoms good.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: This is a token most infallible,
The Jewel that none but the cold hand of Death
Could ravish from him: 'Tis done:
The fear of him is like a storm blown ore:
'Tis done but this is yet but part of that full satisfaction
That must confirm my safetie: Pray my Lord,
You fatal instrument of my Fathers blood,
Let me not look upon you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay Alinda,
You must not be so sad: your gentle sorrow
In those obsequious Tears express'd, shew nature
And Filial pietie as he was your Father:
But think upon your wrongs, my dangers, and your own.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, think you withall, a Father
Is not so early forgot. But sorrow leave me,
And do you give me leave to think, that now
It is no less a Childs part to embrace
Revenge then sorrow for a Fathers loss.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How means my love?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: She lives that was his Ruine.
You may remember whom I mean: Eulalia.
Till now, I had no Plea against her life:
Onely my care of you might wish her Death,
For your security. Her fowl Adultery
And secret Practices against your Crown,
Were nothing unto me, compar'd with this.
Now I have lost a Father: she the cause:
He suffers, she survives: where are your Laws?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet, be content.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Content your self great Sir,
With your black infamie: sit down content
On your Majestick Throne, the President
Of Capital contented Cuckolds, do,
Till all your Subjects dance the Hornpipe too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay dear Alinda, do but think—

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Think what?
What on a course to be reveng'd on you?
To serve you in that kind my self?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O torment!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Or rather, let me think your lustful purpose
Was but to rob me of my Virgin-Honour.
And that you put her by but for a time,
Until my youth had quench'd your Appetite;
Then to recal her home to your embraces.
She is your wife it seems then still: not I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have awak'd me from a Lethargie
In which I was confounded: now I see
She and mine Honour cannot live at once:
She dies, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And you may consider
A little further yet Sir, if you please:
You Father and maintain a Son (your own
I cannot safely say, and therefore more
Is my vexation) who demeans himself
Not towards me, like one that were your wife.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hee's also doom'd already, my Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It may prevent a greater strife hereafter,
Should he but live t'inherit Lands and Titles
That must belong to yours and my succession.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy wisdom inspir'd me: all shall be
(Be thou but my Alinda) rul'd by thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Seal you that Grant: with this kiss I Seal mine:
My glories were eclips'd, but now they shine.

div.head: Scoen. I.
div.stage: Enter Poggio, Lollio, two Countrey-men with Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Y'Are welcome Friends, your prayers and good wishes
Are comforts to me, yet without danger of the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Madam, the Court in all the Braverie
It boasts and borrows, cannot so rejoyce
In the bright shining Beauty of their Queen,
As we in your enjoying in this plainness.
Their Bells, and Bonfires, Tilts and Tournaments,
Their Feasts and Banquets, Musicks and costly shews
( How ere unpaid for) shall not outpass our loves.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Be you as confident, I will not wrong
A man among you: therefore pray reserve
What is your own, and warrant your own safety.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: But how you'll live, we know not: we are now
In our old former Health: the Countrey's cur'd,
Your Practice at an end: unless you had
The common gift of most Physitians,
To make as many sick, as you make sound,
You will not find a Patient in seven years.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: But I have other Arts: sufficient skill
In works of several kinds, the Needle, Loome,
The Wheel, the Frame, the Net-Pin: and choice of
Fingers works are most familiar with me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: And can you handle the Bobbins well, good Woman?
Make statute-Lace? you shall have my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: And mine, to make Tape-Purles: can you do it?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes, and teach all your children works to live on.
The which, together with my own labour,
May bring sufficient for my maintenance:
Without the idle help of Begging, Borrowing,
Or any way infringing the Kings Command.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: You'l have a help beyond himself, but borrowing.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Something I have in Book, to help their knowledge,
And by practise give them literature.
Then when these serious works and studies toil us,
For Recreation, yet with equal skil,
Wee'l practice divers Instruments, Songs and measures,
That shall invite the Powers above to smile
On the content of which we them beguile.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Well Mistris, ours is the voice of the whole Countrey;
All which, or what you please of it, is yours:
Take this House: make your choice of servants.
Take our children: make your own Rates for their Education.
Our Purses and our lives are free to you:
Get what you can, that's your own: will this please you?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes gentle Friends, and with asmuch content
As ere I found in height of Government.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Take your possession then: and let
Posteritie record, that without grieving
A Royal Queen once Traded for her living.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Eho, oh, io, where is my learned sister?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Why seem you so distracted?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Proh Sancto Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Alas what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Hei mihi Qualis erat?
Talis erat qualem nunquam vidi.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Sure, sure, his Scholars have over-Master'd him, and whipt him out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Corpus inane animae, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray speak, what chance has happened?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Non est narrandi locus: Go forth and see. Th'
enraged Rurals are in an uproar lowd, each one an Hercules furens, a formidabilis formidandus Hostis and quite against the Law
sp.l: Of nostrum est injuriam non inferre,
Are on the point of making themselves merry,
In hanging those ill destin'd men by th' neck
That sought so late to give your neck the check.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let us flie to rescue them.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Yet I hope
Your hast will bring you short to cut the Rope.

div.head: Scoen. III.
div.stage: Enter Lollio, Poggio, and guard, with Fabio and Strozza.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Bring 'em away to present execution:
They have lien too long upon the Countreys charge.
We have given 'em bread and water a whole fornight.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: You dare not do't: what Law are we condemn'd by?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Dare we not do't? that word's an hanging matter
Here in our Civil Government: dare not do 't Sir?
Wee'l do't; and when 'tis done, wee'l argue Law with you.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: When you have tane our lives, you'l lay the
Law to us: you cannot be so Barbarous.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Impudent Traytors! how dare you say we cannot? yet because we graciously are pleas'd to put the Law out of our hands, and make you hang your selves, Ile give you Reason: Silence on your lives. First, know, lewd men, y'are Traytors to the King, In offering to be wiser then his Judgement, Which was but Banishment to the good Eulalia:
sp.l: Seeking most Trayterously to take the life
Of (I do not say the Queen, but) the Kings wife
Of most happy memory.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The good Eulalia?

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: the Kings wife?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: That was:
You shall not catch us tripping Sir,
We are more than your match.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Good I do say she is, and good again
I dare pronounce her 〈◊〉 that by dayly pain
Works for her dayly bread: and for bare hire,
Teacheth our children so, that we admire:
The Infants who have understanding more
Then we their Parents have, or then
Our Fore-fathers before us had.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But brother Lollio, make not your speech so long: what is 't to them? they'l carry none on 't to'th other world: let's do what we came to do, e'en hang 'em. Then, as I said, wee'l argle it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: But brother Poggio, better 'tis they live
A minute two or three, then such a Speech
As I am now upon, be lost.
sp.stage: Enter Lodovico, Pedro, Curate, Andrea, Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: See what y' have won by your delay! if she prevent not now
The good we meant her, I dare hang for 'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: In tempore venimus with a Reprieve, quod omnium Rerum est Primum.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Alas, what mean you neighbours? would you now
For all my labours and my Prayers for you,
Blast me with curses of expiring men?
What trespass have I done you, that for me
You put these men to death against my will?

sp.speaker: Fab. Stroz.
sp.l: We do applaud your mercy, gracious Queen.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: There now, there they deserve hanging for that:
They call you Queen, against the Proclamation.
Dare you maintain 'em in't, and now speak for 'em?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: No, I condemn their faults, and blame their lives;
But have nor Power nor will to judge the men:
You have the will; but to assume the Power,
You take the Kings Right from him: you transgresse
As much his Laws in spilling of their blood,
As they had done in mine, had they prevail'd.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: They do not intend to spill their blood, Countrey woman, they would but strangle them: never pierce the skin, nor make 'm an hair worse men, if you consider rightly what they are.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: But to the point. This is the All and some: We meant you a good turn, and for your sake t' have hang'd 'em right or wrong. Now since you will needs stand in your own highway of womens wisdom, which is wilfulness

sp.speaker: (Cur.
sp.p: A most Elegant Figure!) Let'em and please you come to the Gallows another day for killing you out right: who can help it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oraculously spoken: which of the Sages could said more?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: 'Tis not unknown to you, that I can speak like a Sage, and am one of the Sages of our Precinct here for the Laytie, though your learning lie another way among us. I am a Sage, and will be a Sage.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: And so am I, and will be: and but that wise woman, which is as much to say as a fool for her labour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Another elegant Figure.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But that, I say, she has gain-said it, we would; yet to shew our selves Sages, hang 'em up for Scarcrowes, to fright all their fellows for coming from Court to kill women in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: O how I love a Sage! how many Sages do you allow in your Precinct?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Some three or four main Heads: we have now only Pedro, Poggio and my self:
sp.l: But we have many Powers under us:
These now are Powers that execute our Commands.
There is as much difference between a Sage and a Power,
As between a Judge and a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: But is not the learned Curate a Sage amongst ye?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No, as I said before, their learning lies another way: we allow not our Clergie any Temporal Offices, for reasons known unto our selves.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray let me have a Sages place amongst ye then: I long to be a Sage.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Brother Andrea, you shall have my voice in your Election.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Sage Brother Lollio, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: But will ye now, if misericordially
This gracious Foeminine preserve your lives
from the Gallow Tree,
Become new men indeed?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I know they will
When they consider the most dangerous sin,
That threw them on their desperate Attempt,
And their escape from merited Punishment,
They cannot be so graceless, not to turn
To a reformed life: First know, yong men,
Your former Act 'gainst me an Innocent,
Was Perjurie by which I fell, yet flourish.
Consider there how black and fowl your Sin
Is rendred by my Chrystal innocence:
Your next Attempt against me, was blacker, Murder,
The very word sounds horror.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
Name it not then: but by your sacred mercy,
Acquit us of the Doom which we so justly
Have drawn upon our selves: and we will spend
Our lives in rendring satisfaction
To your abused goodness.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This is serious.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Or may the earth on which we kneel for favour,
sp.l: Forc'd by the weight of our detested Sins, open.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Quick devour us.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: So, enough:
Ile take your words.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But now you must reveal
By whom you have been wrought to these fowl Practices.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: All, wee'l discover all, though justly then we pay our lives to Law.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good neighbours, Lollio, Poggio, and Andrea, conduct them to my House.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: My self also will to be their securer convoy go,
For fear the Rusticks may presume again
To stretch these penitent necks with halter strain.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You shall do well: I thank your Charity.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Well, since in these we are prevented thus,
Come more, wee'l hang 'em, or they shall hang us.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Make me but once a Sage, and then fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: Thou shalt be one next Sessions, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: When we have tane these mens confessions,
Ile write at large each passage to the King,
Against the good Eulalia's will or knowledge

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Ile be your faithful Messenger, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thanks my good Pedro: but remember Silence.
So deep in thought good Madam?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Never enough in contemplation of my Happiness.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: It is your Heavenly mind that sweetens all things.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: What's the matter man?
Doubtless and without all peradventure, more miracles.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: The news, good neighbour.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: O neigbours Poggio and Lollio, such a news, such a Discoverie, such a thing is come to pass, such a business is come to light, as your hearts never heard, your Tongues never thought, nor your ears ever utter'd: you cannot hear it, but it will drown you in a Sea of Admiration, never to rise again in your right wits.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Now am I mad till I hear it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Thou shalt tell me first whether it be good or bad, or Ile not hear it.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: It is good or bad I assure you: and therefore you may be gone.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I mean which is it? good or bad?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: I say it is good and bad: and you may both stay and be gone, hear it or hear it not, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay thou art in thy Jibes now: how good or how bad is thy news?
sp.l: I pray thee neighbour, I do pray thee how good or bad is it?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: Nay then it is neither good nor bad, but both: the best and the worst that ever you heard in your life, and the worst shall out first: what do you think of the woman that we have got among us?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Who, the holy woman? that we are all so bound to pray for? I hope no ill's betide her.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: Come, shee's a witch: flatly and plainly said to be a witch.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Did not I tell you she was an unknown woman, and therefore a good one, quoth you? but say I, doubtlesly; and without all peradventure, all that she did was but a kind of witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: It cannot, fie, it cannot be: how is she found so?. I do not say shee's found a witch, but she's accus'd for one.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: By whom is she accus'd?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: By two brave men at Arms that came from Court
With purpose to have kill'd her for the same.
To be short, They found her out, and naked swords they drew:
But as they thought to have thrust her through and through,
They both dead Palsie-struck fall to the ground.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: And had no strength but of their Tongues to wound
The Fame she had.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Vertue can want no Foes,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: With that they cryed she was a witch, and swore
She also was that Queen which for a whore
The King had turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: This is indeed the best news thou couldst bring.
Now doubtlesly and without all peradventure, 'tis the Queen indeed: and if she be not a witch, I am sorry I thought so, with all my heart: where be those men? wee'l hang'm presently.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: No, the Queen, if she be the Queen, will not have them hurt more then they be: we wete about to execute 'em: but she would not suffer it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Goodness it self!

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay without all peradventure, if there be goodness above ground, I said, and I say it again, 'tis in that woman.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p:
She would have cur'd 'em presently her self: but could not do't, because the cruel Caitifs
would not confesse their sins, as she made us, you know, before her gift could cure us: by the same token I suffered an hours torment that I might have scap'd, because I was so loath to bring out that naughtie business betwixt me and the Millers wife.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: 'Twas well you confess'd at last.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: I, and they will be glad to confess, before they be able to stir hand or foot, I warrant: and so I told 'm when I lodg'd 'em both lovingly together upon straw in my Barn, too good for 'em; and so I told 'em too, for being Traytors to her Holiness.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: But where's our Holy woman?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Our Queen wee'l call her now, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Coming this way to her Court-Cottage here, but very slowly, though our two new neighbours make the best way they can for her through the People that press upon her so with thanks and offerings for their new Healths: but she takes not so much for curing of a thousand mortal People, as I have spent in Turpentine and Tarre to keep my Flocklings cleanly in a Spring time. Hark, she comes: this is her Musick where ere she goes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven bless our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Depart good neighbours, good people all depart: shee'l come abroad again to morrow.
Within Heaven bless our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: She thanks you all good People, pray depart,
To morrow you shall have the second part:
She shall appear again unto you; pray depart,
The men in Peace, the Wives in quietness,
And let your bigger children still the less.
Heaven bless our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: So, now the Hubbub's gone: I pray pass on.
I shall be as weary of the Cottage, as of the Court,
If this noise hold: here's thrusting and crowding
As much as there, onely here they have less Pride.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Was ever comfort in the Court like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I never liv'd till now.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Here come more of our weather-headed wise neighbours.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Heaven bless our Holy woman.
Heaven bless your Holiness.
Nay then Heaven bless our Sacred Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This Homage fits not me.
We had not liv'd but by your sacred means;
And will no longer live then be your Subjects.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You go about to cast away your lives:
In serving or in succouring me, you fall
Into Rebellion against the King.
We have no King nor Queen but you.
Heaven bless your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Heaven bless your Majestie.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: That was pronounc'd bravely; O my brave new neighbours!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Y'are Traytors All.
In honouring our Soveraign?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I, well said, hold her to it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: How dare you call me so?
We dare, and can prove it good and lawful.
This Province is engag'd unto you Madam,
The King made it your Joynture: and we find
No reason but you instantly possesse it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What, and the King alive?
He's dead to you.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, he's dead to you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Well said again: that's a sound point, be sworn
These be true Blades.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I tremble but to hear you,
And will not live an hour amongst you more
But with this freedom, To use my fair obedience to the King.
You shall obey the King then, and we'll obey your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let that Title die with my late Fortune:
Remember it no more, but let me be
As one of you; nay rather, an Inferior,
Or I from this abiding must remove:
Of which I first made choice in truth for love.
O Madam!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Take heed good neighbours,
Beware how you give Dignitie or Title; therein you may transgress.
No whit good Madam. Observe the Dialect of France,
And you shall find Madam given there in Courtesie,
To women of low Fortunes, unto whom
'Tis held a poore addition, though great Queens
Do grace and make it Royal.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: 'Tis then the Greatness of
The Person dignifies the Titles, not it the Person.
And in that, Madam, you are in your content
Above all Title's proper to great Princes:
But setting this aside, how thrive your Scholars?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: We go fairly on. [Enter 1. Girl.] look you Sir,
Here's one that knew no letter in the Book
Within these ten days, can read hitherto,
And waits for a new lesson: proceed hither—
And at your hour Ile hear you.

sp.speaker: 1. Girl.
sp.l: Yes forsooth Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p:
Good Girl, well said: nay, nay, hold up your head: so, so, 'tis very well: let's see your Samplar:
what an hearts ease is here! Lod. Right in its perfect Colours.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Nay shee'l do well: now take me out this Flower. Keep your work clean, and you shall be a good Maid. Enter 3. Girl. Now where's your writing book?

sp.speaker: 3. Girl,
sp.p: 'Tis here forsooth. Pray shall I haye a Joyn-hand Copy next?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: No child, you must not Joyn-hand yet: you must your letters and your minums better first. Take heed, you may Joyn-hand too soon, and so mar all: still youth desires to be too forward. Go take your Lute, and let me hear you sing the last I taught you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Whither do you press? who would you speak withall?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: O Sir, for Charity sake give us access unto the holy woman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who are you? or from whence?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We are poor Pilgrims man and wife, that are upon our way struck with sad pain and sorrow.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Alas poor Pilgrims! here's she must do you good.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: How divine Justice throwes my Enemies into my hands? what are your griefes?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: My wife is struck with dumbness.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Hold a little,
That's the greatest grief a woman can endure:
But trouble not thy self to seek for cure.
Too many a man i'th' world will change with thee
A wife that of her Language is too free,
And give good Boot.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray Sir be you silent.
And where's your pain?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here in this hand;
Which I desire to shew in some more privacie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Because your Blow cannot be safely given here, you think.
O sinful wretch! thou hadst no pain till now;
Nor was she dumb till divine Providence
Now at this instant struck her. It is now
Just as thou saist: and justly are you punished
For treacherous counterfeits. Lodowick search his hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: His hand is wither'd, and lets fall a Knife.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: As sharp to do a mischief as ere was felt on.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Now take off his false Beard: see if you know him,
And let the woman be unmuffled.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O Divels!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: O the last couple that came out of Hell!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: These are the other two that damn'd themselves
In perjurie against you at your Tryal.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: How do you master Doctor, and Mistress Midwife?
Is this the Pen your Doctorship prescribes with?
This might soon write that might cure all diseases:
And are these the Labours you go to, Mistress Midnight?
Would you bring women to bed this way?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O damnable conspirators!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray take 'm hence, their time 's not come for cure yet.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Come away Pilgrims: we'll cure 'em for you,
If your own salves can cure you: O my sweet Pilgrims.
Fough, they stink of Treason damnably
What, shall we hang'm? drown 'em? or burn 'em?
They shall taste fortie deaths, then take their own.

sp.p: I, come away with 'em: they shall die fortie times without peradventure,

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: You shall lose me, if you do any violence to any of 'em: but let'm be lodg'd with those we took to day: Ile feed 'em all.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: They'l be a jolly company.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray do as I intreat.
You shall in all command us.

sp.p: Ile make my Barn a spittle for your conspirators till it be top full, and then set fire on't, and please you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Do you no harm, and fear none: send your Children.

sp.speaker: 2. Omn.
sp.l: Long live our Queen.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Your Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?
Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: our School-Mistress, we would say.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: We live secure in spight of Foes: and see,
Where Heaven protects, in vain is Treacherie:
Who says our State is low, or that I fell
When I was put from Court? I did not rise
Till then, nor was advanc'd till now. I see
Heaven plants me 'bove the reach of Treachery.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O happie, happie Saint!
sp.stage: Ex. Rustici with Doct. and Midwife.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.stage: Enter Flavello, alias Alphonso, with a Letter to Eulalia, Poggio and Lollio following.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I would she had a Councel: she shall have a Councel,
And we will be the Heads thereof,
Though I be put to the pains to be President my self.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: It is most requisite for her safety: her danger may be great.
A good guard then in my opinion were more requirable.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: 'Tis well consider'd: she shall have a Guard too: and we will be the limbs thereof, though I be put to the trouble of Captain on't my self.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: You will put on all Offices, yet count 'em pain and trouble.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Yes, and perform 'em too here in our Court of Conscience, for here's no other profit to hinder the Dutie: let them above do what they list; we will have as much care of our School-Mistress, as they of their Semiramis: I speak no Treason nor no trifles neither, if you mark it. But she must never know this care of ours, She'll urge the Statute of Relief against it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: This is some Courtier sure that's with her; he smells illfavordly.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: That made me dog him hither.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: He shall not have her out of sight, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Nor out of reach neither: a mischief's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: No Superscription, nor any names unto it. Most Royal and most wronged Soveraign Mistress: (that must needs be me.) Be happily assured your Restauration is at hand; And by no less means then by her Death that usurps your Dignitie: (a plain conspiracie against Alinda in my behalf.) All shall be determined at Nicosia, by
Your Loyal Servants.
Nameless.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: You know not the contents then, and are bound by Oath you say not to reveal the senders of this Letter.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It is most true: onely thus much I tell you, they are your noble and best chosen Friends.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Heaven! can it be, that men in my respect can plunge into such danger?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: So Madam, this being all I had in charge,
I must crave leave (indeed I do not like this
Oportunitie, nor well the countenances of these Hobnols.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You are no messenger of such ill Tidings
To part so slightly: indeed you shall not.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: She's honied with the newes: I have already
Madam my Reward, and will no longer stay.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Then I must say, you shall stay: or Ile send
A cry as loud as Treason after you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You'l wrong yourself and Friends then.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: You wrong your self Sir, and we charge you stay.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By the command of Peasants?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: How! you choplogical Rascal, Peasants!

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Down with him into utter darkness.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: No-violence good Friends: but if you will detain him
Till I give order for his libertie,
You do the State good service.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: May it do you Service?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: The State is finely serv'd already.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Me most of all.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Hell cannot hold him faster then.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Mad Asse, hold your prating till she calls you:
Mean time you are fast: 'twas time we were a Councel or a Guard.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I thank thee Providence, I dreamed not of such ready help.
I am struck through with wonder at this Letter:
I could not at the first but think't a Bayt
To catch my willingness to such an Act;
Or Gullerie to mock my Hopes or wishes,
In case I had such: therefore I desired
The Messengers restraint from being my Relator:
But now a strong Belief possesses me,
A noble Fury has stirr'd up some Friends
To this high enterprize: whereby I gather
My cause is weigh'd above, whence I shall see
How well my patience over-rules my wrong,
And my Foes ruin'd with mine Honours safety.
But let my better Judgement weigh those thoughts,
I do not seek revenge, why shall I suffer it?
My causeless injuries have brought me Honour,
And 'tis her shame to hear of my mis-hap.
And if by Treachery she fall, the world
Will judge me accessarie, as I were indeed
In this foreknowledge of the foul intent,
Should I conceal it.
Then here's the trembling doubt which way to take:
Whether to rise by her Destruction,
Or sink my Friends, discovering their pretence.
Friends have no Priviledge to be treacherous:
She is my Soveraignes wife, his chief content;
Of which to rob him, were an act of horrour
Committed on himself. The question's then,
Whether it be more foul ingratitude
To unknown Friends, and for an act of Sin,
Then to be treacherous to the Prince I love?
It is resolv'd: Ile once more see the Court.
O my good Patrons, I must now intreat
Means for my Journey to attend the King,
On a discoverie for the present safetie
Of his fair Queen: she will be murder'd else.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: And let her go: we have shut up your news-bringer safe enough, will keep you by your favour, short enough from hindring such a work.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Dear Friends, a small matter will prevent this world of dangers.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Would you have us to become Traytors, to
Supply your wants against the Proclamation?
If you be well, remain so: your industry
Can keep you here: but for a Journey, that
Requires Horses and Attendants: money must he had,
Which we have not for such an idle purpose.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O hear me.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Will you neglect your House and Trade to meddle any more with State-matters?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: And bring our necks in danger to assist you?
Let your own counsell advise you to stay.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How died the Boy?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gonzago Sir, your Son?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Son, my Son? you urge the name of Son
To work remorse within me, when I ask
How died that Bastard Boy; no Son of mine.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: His last words that he spake to me, were these;
Go, tell the King my Father, that his frown
Hath pierc'd my heart: tell him, if all his Land
Be peopled with obedient hearts like mine,
He needs no lawes to second his displeasure,
To make a general Depopulation:
But that he may not lose so much, I pray
That in my Death his misse-plac'd anger die,
And that his wrath have double force 'gainst those
That to his Person and his Laws are Foes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And then, as if the Spirit of Prayer
Had onely been habitual in his soul,
He did implore Heaven's goodness to come down,
Lifting him hence to shine upon your Crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This Boy yet might be mine, though Sforza might have wrong'd me by the By.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: This done, he pray'd me leave the Roome. I wept: In sooth I could-not chuse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, well, you wept, return'd, and found him dead in's Bed you say.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, in so sweet a Posture, as no Statuarie
With best of skill on most immaculate Marble
Could fashion him an Image purer, slighter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I found his stretch'd-out fingers which so lately
Had clos'd his eyes, still moistned with his tears;
And on his either cheek a tear undryed,
Which shone like Stars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It seems he wept and died.
Prithee no more: I cannot though forget
My threatnings were too sharp: I must forget it.
I charge you that you leavy up our Army
Against those Rebels that we hear give succour
Unto the wretched cause of all my mischiefes,
That hated ill-liv'd woman.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my dread liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The matter? speaks; how does the Queen?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O the sweet Queen! I fear, I fear, I fear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What fearst thou? speak the worst I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I fear she has a Moonflaw in her brains:
She chides and fights that none can look upon her.
Her Fathers Ghost, in her I think: here she comes.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Where's this King? this King of Clouts,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Fearful effect of Pride!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: This shadow of a King, that stands set up
As in a Press among the Raggs and Vizors
That represent his deceas'd Ancestors.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What means my love?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Your love? where is your love?
Where is the preparation that you promis'd
Of strength to tear in pieces that vile Witch
That lives my souls vexation? your love?
You are a load of torment: your delays
To my desires are Hellish cruelties.
Are these your Promises?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have given order with all speed I could.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You could cut off an old man in a Prison,
That could make no resistance, and you could
Vex a poor Boy to death, that could but cry
In his defence; that you could do; but this
That has so much shew of fear or hardness,
As a few Peasants to maintain a Strumpet
Against your Dignitie, is too much to do
For a poor coward King.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What a tyrannous Ambition
Has the Devil puff'd up this Bladder with!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I fear her wits are craz'd indeed. Alinda,
Hear me gentle love.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O my torment!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As I am true to the Crown, I know not what to say to this: she's falling mad sure.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No, no, you dare not do't: your Army may
Perhaps i'th' dangerous Action break a shin,
Or get a bloody nose: it now appears
My Father (as 'twas voyc'd) was all your valour.
Y' have never a Mars or Cuckold-making General
Now left: and for your self, you'r past it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: His 'tother wife would not have us'd him thus.
Quiet Cuckoldrie is better then scolding chastitie all the world over.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I see distraction in her face.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Did all your brave Commanders die in Sforza?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By the Kings favour Madam (not to stir
The dust of your dead Father) he has Souldiers
That know to lead and execute no less
Then did victorious Sforza.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.p: Sirrah! you have stirr'd more then his dust; you have mov'd his blood in me, unto a Justice that claims, they trayterous head.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My head? and Trayterous? I do appeal unto the King.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: A King? a Cobweb.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And she the Spider in't I fear.
My Loyaltie knowes not how to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: If thou beest King, thou yet art but that King
That ows me love and life, and so my subject.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Indeed Alinda;—

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Yes indeed Gonzago,
Life by inheritance: for my valiant Father
Whose life thou tookst, gave thine, and so 'tis mine.
And for your love, you dare not wrest it from me;
Therefore deny not now my just demand,
In that proud Traytors head.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She's mad beyond all cure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Examine his offence, my dear Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is't not enough Alinda doth command it?
Are these the Articles you gave me grant of?
Is this the nothing that you would deny me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet, weigh but his offence.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: His Head is my offence: and give me that
Now, without pause, or by the strength of Hercules
Ile take thee by the Horns, and writhe thine own off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go from her sight Petruccio; levie up our Forces,
And let the Boy Gonzago be embowell'd,
And sent as a forerunner of our Furie
Unto that Witch, contriver of these woes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis done, my liege.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Was ever woman barr'd her will, as I am?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Here's a fine woman spoil'd now, by humoring her at first, and cherishing her Pride.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Sure you have but mock'd me all this while:
I am no wife, no Queen, but silly Subject.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis a disease in her that must be sooth'd:
Sweet, thou shalt have his Head.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O, shall I so?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go in, it shall be brought thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Mark what I say to bind you to your word:
Do it, or Ile not love you: I can change
Love into hate, hate into love most sweetly:
Let that man live to morrow, Ile love him,
And do fine feats with him, such as your tother wife
And Sforza did; but make much better sport on't.
They were an old dry couple.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Take this, take all.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I leave all to your Kingly consideration:
You know your charge: look to't, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What wild Affections do in women raign!
But this a Passion past all President.
O 'tis meer Madness, mix'd with Divellish cunning,
To hurl me upon more and endless mischiefes:
It has awak'd me to the sight of those
My fury (sprung from Dotage) hath already
Laid in my Path, grim Spectacles of horror,
The blood of Sforza, and that tender Boy:
O let me think no further, yet stay there:
To plunge at first into too deep a Sense
Of soul-afflicting terrours, drowns the Reason,
And stupifies the Conscience, which delivers
Us over to an insensibilitie
Of our misdeeds, and of our selves: just Heaven!
Afford me light to see I am misled:
But let it not as lightning blast mine eyes,
Confound my Senses, make me further stray,
For ever coming back to know my way.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How fares your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O Horatio! shee's lost, shee's lost, Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would my wife were with her then:
And so would any good Subject say; I think.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What dost thou think?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Marry I think (and so would any good Subject think, I think) as your Majestie thinks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What dost thou think of Loyaltie now?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Truly I think there's now not any warrantable Loyaltie left but in Petruccio and my self.
The Queen is now out of my Catalogue, and my Creed too.

div.head: Scoen. VIII.
div.stage: [A shout within] crying, Kill him, kill him: for Sforza, Sforza: kill him for the blood of Sforza, Sforza, &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What terrible, what hideous noise is this?
Kill him for Sforza, Sforza; kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Loyaltie defend me! I know not what to make on't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What art thou? speak: hadst thou the voice of Hell,
Denouncing all the Furies in't, I dare yet hear thee; speak.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O mighty Sir, Petruccio.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What of Petruccio?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O Petruccio! I tremble but to speak him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shall I then with the Prophetique Spirit of a King
Speaks of Petruccio? he is turn'd Traytor,
And animates the Souldiers against me,
Upon the discontent Alinda gave him
Now in her Fury: is't not so?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis so, 'tis so: ne'er ask him for the matter:
I thought so, just, just as your Majestie thought it;
And find withall, that now you have not left
A Loyal heart but in Horatio's bosome,
Now that Petruccio fails: I fear'd 'twould come
To that: nay knew't: O hang him, hang him,
False hearted villain! he was never right,
And so I always told your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The cry comes neerer still: what does he mean,
To bring my Army on to Massacre
Me in my House?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Dread Sir, vouchsafe attention:
Petruccio is Loyal: 'tis his Loyaltie,
And most sincere obedience to your will,
That brings him to the ruine of his life,
Unless your aweful Presence make prevention.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is then his Loyaltie become his danger?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: As thus great Sir, in the late Execution
Of Death-doom'd Sforza, which the Souldier
(Not looking on your Justice, but the Feud
That was betwixt Petruccio and him)
Resents as if it were Petruccio's Act,
Not yours, that cut him off: and still, as madly
Bewitch'd with Sforza's love, as ignorant
Of the desert of brave Petruccio,
They all turn head upon him: and as if
'Twere in his power to new create him to them,
They cry to him for Sforza, Sforza; or if not,
Petruccio's life must answer Sforza's blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Left you him in that distress?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: He did prevail
With much entreatie, by some private reasons,
Upon their fury for an hours respite:
In which dear time 'tis onely you may save
Guiltless Petruccio from a timeless Grave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art a Souldier, art not?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: And have commanded in your Highnesse Wars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Me thinks I should remember, but Ile trust thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I hope you'll be advis'd, though, how you run
Into this wild-fire of Rebellion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Fortune is more desperate then his:
I am beset and circled in with mischiefes.
Way-laid with heaps of dangers every where:
Yet I will on: Kings were not made to fear.
Ile fetch him off, and the more readily,
For my misprision of his Loyaltie.
Could I think that man false?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No Sir, nor I:
By all meanes fetch him off: that Loyal General
Is tenfold worth the whole Rebellious Army:
Save him, and hang them all.
sp.stage: Enter Petruccio with a Rabble of Souldiers, and two Captains, crying, Come, come, away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Have you no Faith, nor due obedience
Unto the King? this outrage is 'gainst him,
In me he suffers.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: We obey the King,
And 'tis his Justice that we cut your throat,
For doing such outrage in the death of our brave General,
That had you lives more then false drops of blood,
They were not all sufficient satisfaction for his losse.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: Your limited hour draws on apace: Prepare.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He's come within that hour, that shall relieve me.
Where is he? is he come?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You are betray'd:
He's fled and gone: no such man to be found.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then Faith is fled from man: is Sforza fled?
Why should I wish to live, now Honour's dead?
Now take your bloody course, and in my fall,
Martyr the man that sav'd your General.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Sav'd him? how sav'd?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sforza lives.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's that? how's that? that, that again.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: As I now live, I set him free from Prison,
Trusting unto his Honour to secure me,
In which I did abuse the Kings Authoritie
To th' forfeit of my life.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: This sounds: this sounds.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: But does this sound well from a Souldiers mouth?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: He is not now worthy of death, before He be well whipt for lying.
The King, the King, the King!

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: He could never come in a better time, to see how bravely we will do justice for him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How comes this Fury rais'd amongst ye Souldiers?
Have you forgot my Laws and Person too?

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: We honour both thus low: now gives us leave
To look like men, and give your Highness welcome
To see a General of your Election
Die with a lie in's mouth: your Souldier here,
None of the good Queens old ones.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dare you both judge and execute this man?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: We dare to kill the Hangman of our General,
And think it fits our Office best: though you
Have Law enough to wave our care and pain,
And hang him up your self: for he affirms
That he let Sforza live 'gainst your command;
And that's the lie we treat of.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Ile give you all your Pardons, and him Honour,
To make that true. Sfor. Your Kingly word is taken.
Noble Petruccio, thou art disengag'd:
And if the temper of the Kings high Anger
Blow still above his Justice, let it crush
This cloud that holds a shower of innocent blood,
Willing to fall and calm his violent fury.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Our General lives: a Sforza, Sforza.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sforza!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You have outdone me in Nobilitie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am all wonder: now this man appears
The Mansion and habitual Seat of Honour;
Of which he seems so full, there cannot be
An Angle in his breast to lodge so base
An Inmate as disloyaltie: if so,
How was Eulalia false? or how Gonzago,
That tender Boy, the fruit of lawless lust?
There I am lost again: Great Power, that knowest
The subtletie of hearts, shew me some light
Through these Cymmerian mists of doubts and fears,
In which I am perplex'd even to distraction:
Shew me, shew me yet the face of glorious Truth; where I may read
If I have err'd, which way I was misled.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Enters. O my dread Lord!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy news?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my sweet Soveraign!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou distracted too?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No Sir: The Queen, the Queen, the Queen's distracted,
And I am like to be, and you, and any man
That loves the King, unless some Conjurer
Be found to lay the Devil: I mean Sforza.
Sforza Sir (would you think?) that monstruous Traytor
Sforza walks in the Court without a Head;
Appear'd unto the Queen: I found her talking with him,
Kneeling and praying him to give her Pardon;
Told him indeed 'twas she that sought his Head,
And that she thought, that being now a Queen,
She might by her Prerogative take Heads,
Whose and as many as she listed: but
She promis'd she would send it him again,
Or else Petruccio's first: or if he would forgive her
This time, shee'ld do so no more.
He seem'd he would not hear her: then she beat
Her self against the walls and floor, and flies
To free her self by th' windows: calls for Poison,
Knife, Rope, or any thing, whereby to follow
Her most abused Father. What to make on't,
As I am true to th' Crown, I must refer
Onely unto your Majestie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O 'tis fearful!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Lord, you saw not th' Apparition, did you?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not I: I saw him not: nor has the Devil
Power in a Traytors shadow to appear
Unto a Loyal Subject. Hah! my Loyaltie
And Truth unto the Crown defend me!
See the very foresaid Devil at my Elbowe,
Head and all now: avoid, attempt me not Satan,
I do conjure thee by all the vertues of a Loyal Courtier.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: They are all too weak to charm a Devil Sir;
But me they may, your Friend.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I defie thee Bubsebel.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What do you see, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look there, the Apparition, there it is;
As like the Traytor Sforza when he liv'd,
As Devil can be like a Devil— oh!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Fear not: he lives, and Loyal to the King.
